awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project involves three community colleges of the Seattle Community Colleges District VI.  The Ready! Set! Transfer! 2.0 (RST 2.0) project conducted by North Seattle College, South Seattle College, and Seattle Central College will provide scholarships and other support for talented, low-income students pursuing careers and transfer associate degrees in astronomy, biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering, geology, mathematics, nanotechnology, oceanography, and physics. In addition to scholarships, support activities include faculty mentoring, advising and transfer workshops, and a STEM speaker series of research and industry representatives. A particular emphasis will be placed on studying the unique challenges facing STEM students who begin their studies in developmental mathematics. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain STEM degrees, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well being of the nation.

The Ready! Set! Transfer! 2.0 (RST 2.0) project is based on the results from a prior NSF-supported STEM Talent Expansion Program (STEP)project to the Seattle Colleges District VI.  The colleges will utilize resources and the momentum from this prior STEP award to build community among scholars and provide a rich collection of evidence-based co-curricular supports to foster retention and completion. This team of three community colleges will work in collaboration with educational researchers from Seattle University to better understand the unique challenges facing STEM students who begin their studies in developmental mathematics. This collaboration will contribute to the knowledge base of STEM education by investigating how mechanisms of structural inequality related to social class stratify the experiences and opportunities of STEM students who begin their studies in developmental mathematics. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community. The project team will communicate with local and national audiences to share insights developed from the qualitative and quantitative investigation of the impacts of co-curricular supports on talented low-income students.

por.por_cntn:
An expanded scientific, technical, engineering, and math (STEM) workforce unlocks the potential for innovation by utilizing diverse backgrounds and perspectives. In addition, it strengthens scientific endeavors and bolsters the nation's competitiveness on a global scale. Two-year colleges are particularly well-positioned to expand and diversify this workforce. The RST 2.0 project, an NSF-funded S-STEM program, sought to increase the number of students successfully transferring from two-year colleges into baccalaureate degree granting programs in STEM. RST 2.0 provided scholarships and extracurricular support to 261 academically promising STEM students with unmet financial need from across three of the Seattle Colleges: North Seattle College, Seattle Central College, and South Seattle College. RST 2.0 coordinators at each of the three colleges provided an array of evidence-based supports to the RST 2.0 scholars including mentoring, workshops, speakers, fieldtrips, and internships, all designed to improve STEM identity and belonging in the scholarship recipients. The work was informed by both rigorous evaluation and the involvement of an educational researcher who conducted a longitudinal ethnography to better understand the experiences of low-income students as they navigated their first two years of college, with a particular focus on students who began their academic journey in developmental math and the impacts of online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic. Four publications and numerous conference presentations were produced as a result of this research.

A comparison of the RST scholars and the overall composition of students seeking Associates of Science (AS) degrees in Fall of 2023 at all three colleges demonstrates that the program was particularly successful at reaching promising students from historically marginalized populations in STEM. For example, Black or African American-identifying students made up 17.7% of RST Scholars and 12.9% of all AS degree-seeking students across the three Seattle Colleges; similarly, female-identifying students make up just 36% of AS degree seekers at the Seattle Colleges while 44% of RST scholars were female-identifying. Student surveys and interviews confirm that the RST 2.0 scholarship was a critical support for students. Most of the scholars (91%) identified their mentors as one of the most impactful components of the program, agreeing that the mentors helped them understand the steps necessary for successful transfer and made them feel part of a STEM community. 

The RST 2.0 project resulted in several lasting, positive changes to the Seattle Colleges, including a renewed focus on strategies to minimize barriers for low-income STEM students, a pool of trained faculty mentors, and a sustained commitment to providing undergraduate research experiences to students during their time at the Seattle Colleges in order to continue to best recruit, retain, and educate a diverse, robust generation of STEM workers and researchers.


Last Modified: 03/15/2024
Modified by: Ann J Murkowski
